question: A level 1 human Fighter with the Dueling fighting style uses the help action to assist another player. Does the advantage apply to damage rolls?

Section Fighter > Class Features > Fighting Style > Dueling
rules_explanation: The rules on the Help action don't include any additional benefit to damage rolls. Dueling only provides a bonus to damage rolls with a one-handed melee weapon.

question: If a half-orc fighter uses the relentless endurance feature to drop to 1 hit point instead of zero hit points, and the attack that would have reduced them to zero was a critical hit, how many death saving throw failures are applied?

Section Combat > Dropping to 0 Hit Points > Death Saving Throws

question: How is damage calculated for creatures in the area of an earthquake spell?
answer: The damage is calculated using the rule for structures. The tremor deals 50 bludgeoning damage to any structure in contact with the ground in the area when you cast the spell and at the start of each of your turns until the spell ends.

question: In a world where it is nighttime all the time, does light radius of a wight change?

question: Does the Lucky feat allow you to reroll a 2 on 2d6 necrotic damage rolled for the bite attack of a Vampire Spawn who's an NPC that you have just critically hit?

Section Gameplay Basics > Using Ability Scores > Attack Rolls
rules_explanation: The Lucky feat only applies to the d20 roll, and does not in any way affect damage. The conditions governing critical hits and melee attacks are not relevant to this case.

question: If a character is on the ground and has the grappled condition, can they crawl? If so, how far can they move?
answer: A grappled creature's speed becomes 0, and it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed. To move while prone, you must crawl. Every foot of movement while crawling costs 1 extra foot.
rules: Section Combat > Movement and Position > Being Prone
Section Conditions > Grappled
Section Combat > Movement and Position > Difficult Terrain
rules_explanation: The grappled condition sets speed to zero so a creature would be unable to stand without some other condition changing their speed. The crawling definition tells you how much movement it costs per foot to crawl (2 feet), and the difficult terrain section indicates that such terrain costs an additional foot of movement, bringing the total spent to 3 feet of movement for every 1 foot crawled through difficult terrain.

question: What happens when you try to cast a spell with a casting time longer than a single action or reaction?
answer: When you cast a spell with a casting time longer than a single action or reaction, you must spend your action each turn casting the spell, and you must maintain your concentration while you do so. If your concentration is broken, the spell fails, but you don't expend a spell slot. If you want to try casting the spell again, you must start over.
rules: Section Spellcasting > Casting a Spell > Casting Time > Longer Casting Times
rules_explanation: This information is directly quoted from the SRD.
